pullRequest.body:
* Make many safe Aesop rules in the SetLike ruleset either unsafe or (additionally) simp lemmas
* Add new Aesop rules `<SubStructure>.closure_mem_of_mem` and `mem_of_star_mem`
* Replace `simps` auto-generated lemmas around `StarAlgebra.adjoin` with an Aesop-registered API
* Add new library note [SetLike Aesop ruleset] explaining the principles behind the new design

The `simps` auto-generated lemmas I have removed produced messy output that harmed the performance of simp and Aesop without being particularly usable. The new API brings `StarAlgebra.adjoin` and friends in line with anlogous operations elsewhere in Mathlib.

Moves (incidental):
`NonUnitalSubalgebra.starClosure_toNonunitalSubalgebra` -> `NonUnitalSubalgebra.starClosure_toNonUnitalSubalgebra`

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I am sorry; I am not competent to evaluate this PR.

[CI run](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12932005672)

Everything looks sensible and the library note is pristine (thanks 🙏). However, there are some minor slowdowns and incidentally I see quite a few different things happening in this PR. For the sake of reducing the diff and isolating the performance hit, would you mind splitting off:
* A PR adding the missing `adjoin`/`closure` lemmas (the ones that are not solely for aesop use)
* A PR tagging lemmas with simp (I suspect this is the performance hit)
* A PR cleaning up the unnecessary `unsafe` and `apply` clauses in the aesop atagging
This doesn't mention success probabilities of 50% or 99%. Given that you are introducing some of those in this PR, can you clarify where they fit in the picture?
Shouldn't be any at 99%. I'll write a line about stuff between 5% and 90% (it's just vibes)
Wait, how come simps generate a misspelled lemma name `starClosure_toNonunitalSubalgebra`?
It didn't -- see [old] lines 588-592. The theorem ordering here has been made consistent with other files.
Then I don't understand why you are removing the `simps!` on `starClosure`

`simps!` generates the following simp lemma:

`starClosure_carrier  ... : ↑S.starClosure = ⋂ s, ⋂ (_ : ↑(NonUnitalSubsemiring.closure (↑S ∪ star ↑S)) ⊆ ↑s), ↑s`.

This is not a desirable `simp` normal form, and indeed no other closure operations have this simp lemma except `StarSubalgebra.adjoin` and friends. I've replaced these auto-generated simp lemmas with the usual closure interface, which mostly uses `aesop`.

hmm, on second thoughts this shouldn't have this interface since it's analogous to `Submonoid.subsemiringClosure` rather than `Submonoid.closure`. However the definition still shouldn't be simp-reducible to a pile of garbage. I'll copy the `Submonoid.subsemiringClosure` interface for this.
done!

Adding `@[simp]` here (which looks good to me) should make `@[aesop]` unnecessary since `simp` will already solve any goal to which the Aesop rule could apply. Could you check whether removing `@[aesop]` breaks anything? Similar below.

I don't think this is quite right -- in the original implementation, this rule is intended to complement the "loopy" rule `mem_subset_of_mem` by assigning a sensible metavariable, which isn't posible in the `simp` phase. See also my new set-ups for `zero_mem` and `one_mem`, which are both `simp` and `aesop safe`. In any case, this usage *should* have been strictly superseded by my new lemma `mem_adjoin_of_mem`, which I introduced to avoid precisely the highly heartbeat-inefficient application of `mem_subset_of_mem` followed by metavariable assignment.
Makes sense, thanks!

FYI, you can shorten this to `@[aesop 80% (rule_sets := [SetLike])]`. When a percentage is given, `unsafe` is assumed, and `apply` is the default rule builder for anything that doesn't look like an equation or tactic.
Why is `@[simp]` removed here?
It's a special case of `ZeroMemClass.zero_mem`, which now has a `simp` attribute.

As you correctly note in the design notes (which are very good btw!), loopy rules such as this one tank Aesop performance. So maybe they should go into a separate rule set (`SetLike!`?) that can be activated when needed.

That's a good idea; I'll do that for all the loopy rules. Note that pretty much all rules have the potential to be loopy due to metavariable assignment, and this is a good thing because it allows Aesop to construct simple witnesses for existential goals.

To be clear: I'm only putting the rules that loop/create metavariables in `SetLike!`. So far this is just `mem_subset_of_mem` and `mem_of_star_mem`. I'm keeping lemmas like `mul_mem` which generate mvars and loop only in the presence of mvars in `SetLike`.
Can this be `@[simp]` instead of `@[aesop]`? Ditto for the next two changes.
Oh yep thanks!

```suggestion
  a higher probability the more specific their conclusions and the more generic their hypotheses are.
```
Is it? It's of the form `?a ∈ f ?s` instead of `f ?a ∈ ?s`. I don't really see the difference

hmm
in practice the operations on the LHS are the most restrictive thing
like generally the RHS stays the same and the LHS varies
not sure if I'm describing well
Not sure I'm convinced 🤔

in practice, what is happening is the expression on the LHS is being broken up by repeated applications
and then at the end you close the atomic goals with stuff like `mem_closure_of_mem`
idk how to make this precise
OK what I mean is: in practice, if you have a goal of the form `f ?_ ∈ g ?_`, you want to prioritise getting rid of the `f` over getting rid of the `g`.
Probably worth explaining the distinction in the library note, then

```suggestion

Some examples of membership-related goals which Aesop this ruleset is designed to close
```
else your paragraph will get eaten by the list

Accident?
```suggestion
variable (R)
```
This looks like unrelated cleanup

accident
I'll just make a separate PR doing all of these at once, as you suggest
Same here

pullRequest.title: feat(Aesop): Improve SetLike ruleset

[CI run](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/12932005672)

Everything looks sensible and the library note is pristine (thanks 🙏). However, there are some minor slowdowns and incidentally I see quite a few different things happening in this PR. For the sake of reducing the diff and isolating the performance hit, would you mind splitting off:
* A PR adding the missing `adjoin`/`closure` lemmas (the ones that are not solely for aesop use)
* A PR tagging lemmas with simp (I suspect this is the performance hit)
* A PR cleaning up the unnecessary `unsafe` and `apply` clauses in the aesop atagging
